column4: So I'm gonna be a bit of a compile noob here for a minute and ask what else do I need to do to make ipset 4.4 work as a kernel module under ubuntu 10.10 server now that I have done a make & make install using the KERNEL_SRC= directive ???
gcc - o exploit your0wned.c
Wow, arent you helpful
are you being sarcastic?
No worse thenyou with the "gcc -o exploit yourOwned.c"  bit
I must have been mistaken I thought you wanted to hack the  Gibson?
Nah, I just want ipset to work
welcome to my world, looking for real support
just venting on you, sorry
My prob is that using mudule-assistant to make the 2.5 module version of ipset pukes.  I can and have compiled the 4.4 version from source but it installed it to my user dir
No worries... I can take it as well as I can dish it too
does make install not give you any options for ipset?
It all ended up in my home folder
New error message at least
I suppose this is progress:  FATAL: Module ip_set not found.
standbye I got like 50 PM's
lucky you!  Hopefully to help fix your issue!
they are everyones issues
is there anyway I can just add what I've compiled since I see all the files in my home folder?
or for that matter, use module-assistant to use the src I downloaded?
you want to recompile kernel to include ... ?
Should work as a module
Did in 10.04 anyway
im with you now
Right ... all the files compiled and are sitting in a directory  ( for ipset 4.4) but I either need to recompile with module-assistant specifying the 4.4 source or manually install the compiled files
Hopefully that made sense
give me a moment, I know what you want. When you ran make it should have asked you about ipset
the dist of ipset for ubuntu is broken and the src from ubuntu errors on compile hence why I went for 4.4 version instead of packaged 2.5
did you do a...
I followed the directions at http://ipset.netfilter.org/install.html
standbye let me look
and I did use the kernel_dir with the compile
gonna re-do it right now
good idea
Problem is that instead of putting the mod files in the proper mod directory it installs them to my home directory
I perfer old school
i understand, but it shouldntt make a diff
does ubuntu support 'make menuconfig' ?
Not sure
try it
no rule for it
can you do a 'make dep' + 'make clean' + 'make'?
no rule for dep
also try make with insmod
negative
also try make with insmod
lemme do a pastebin
http://paste.ubuntu.com/523636/
Did the pastebin explain it better?
yeah hold on
Gotta love it when documentation is vague or lacking
from what I can see, and somewhat shot in the dark. Is your kernel does not support to the module your trying to add
it shoudl as there was kernel support in the last version of ubuntu ( 10.04) where I used module-assistant to put in 2.5.0 of ipset
unfortunately the make dep doesnt work as there is no target to make it
I would have used 2.5 again had it not puked on compile
bugtraq?
nothing there... already checked
I think your issues are above incl module IPV6
not using ipv6 at all
yep
there is no rule to make dep
every kernel, everr made
here's the build log form module-assistant when I tried to use it to make the 2.5.0 module:  http://paste.ubuntu.com/523644/
well looks good you did make clean
no rule to make target .... remember, I'm not making the whole kernel, just a module
your issue lies in make dep
that last pastebin is the old way of getting ipset to work with the kernel, current version of ubuntu pukes and fails when it tries to work
thats the best I can do.. is *GUESS* your missing dep
appreciated but even when i run m-a a-i ipset , it fails
still can be missing dependencies
what a pain in the arse this has become.  I think I'm gonna go back to 10.04 and be done with it since it worked
IMHO I would ditch Ubuntu all together
which distro would you reccomend?
I am sure your issue is somewhere with Kernel dependency
I have been so far removed from Linux distros you wouldn' want to ask
so go to slackware or similar?
this used to work btw:  http://www.jsimmons.co.uk/2010/06/08/using-ipset-with-iptables-in-ubuntu-lts-1004-to-block-large-ip-ranges/
I would go debian or slackware...Ubuntu is a end all be all desktop solutuion that does none of the above good
trying a last ditch effort atm
I know make dep, make clean, make will work to put your module in to the kernel, on Debian...Ubuntu seems to be a Win7 distro of Debian. Easy to use on a 'default' sys
this is their server version
see if you can find a distro of SUSE
non Novell molested
try debian I think you will like it
you made my day man, thanks for the chat
you too.  Appreciate the help
love to bullshit when you have time, look me up
love to CHAT with YOU next TIME! no fould LANGUAGE I PROMISE!
LOL screw em if they cant take a slang
I guess it isn't their fault, default language scripts ... :D
I'll show you why I need ipset... just a sec
